title: The Head-Spinning Reason Conservatives Are Upset About This Ad

comments.text:
I see myself as a decent person and the "issue" here is very clear. People 
assume American soldiers and Muslims are enemies, and therefore they think 
is it not ok for the two to be together. This is considered much more 
controversial in Israel, and that still happens.

As much as I dislike religion, if two people want to be together, the 
religion, sex, or gender of either/both of them doesn't matter to me at 
all, for all I care, you could be a frum Jew or an IDF soldier, with a 
Muslim that prays 5 times a day. Just don't be assholes toward others. 
Thanks in advance.﻿
comments.author: Liran Piade

comments.text:

comments.author: Joe Shorts

comments.text:
When watching the ad I couldn't help but wonder why an ad for an 
anti-snoring spray would need a muslim in it. Of course if the actress was 
a muslim and therefor wanted to wear her hijab, no problem at all. Yet this 
actress obviously wasn't muslim, or at least not the kind of muslim that 
wears a hijab, because she showed her hair before that in the ad.
There is the obvious reason that the controversy it would create would be 
advertisment on its own, but apart from that, how is wearing a hijab 
sending a message that has anything to do with an anti-snoring spray?

(of course, the reaction of Fox News is over the top, but that still 
doesn't explain the ad)﻿

comments.text:
The supermarket nearest to me has the very pretty lady who works there.  
She wears the head scarf.  Now, am I supposed to believe that that soldier 
with PTSD will go berserk upon seeing that billboard, but WON'T go berserk 
when he sees a real live Muslim woman standing right in front of him asking 
if he noted the price on parsnips?  If I believe what this woman tweeted, I 
have to believe that soldiers with PTSD should never be allowed in public, 
and I know better than that.

Let's not forget that we're dealing with people who thought that the 
Cherrios ad was controversial, and who nearly lost it (much worse than that 
soldier seeing a billboard will) over *America the Beautiful* sung in 
multiple languages.﻿

conservatives don't like it. I consider myself to be fiscally conservative

ANYTHING wrong with this ad. The people who have a problem with this ad are

comments.author: Kevin Morthorst

comments.text:
If I'd just seen this advertisement and was told that there was controversy 
around it, I'd assume that it was coming from liberal viewers thinking that 
the treatment of a mixed marriage was far too heavy handed. The fact that 
there was nothing of any interest in the ad apart from the fact that she 
was wearing a headscarf and he military garb means that the fact that she 
was a muslim and he a soldier was what was meant to draw the audience's 
attention and thus make the product stand out. This along with the tagline 
"keeping you together" actually suggests that their marriage was at risk, 
presumably although unstated, because of her religion and his job. I found 
the ad incredibly patronising as it reminded me of tv shows that exchange 
development of a character with simply not conforming to an expected 
stereotype: "she's black but she plays the oboe", "oh really I thought she 
was going to knife me in the gut", "he wears a turban and a kilt", 
"complex!".﻿

comments.text:
Now that's a good question.

Theory: It's easier for the average American to except a female Muslim with 
a American soldier than visavera. When we see ads for the military, it's 
mostly male soldiers who are labeled "The Proud". 

Another reason is that the stereotypical Muslim male is often viewed in our 
culture as being apart of the male-dominated radical Islam, such as  ISIS 
and Boko Haram, and while this would have been more controversial, it may 
not have been very marketable considering that Muslim women are perceived 
as less threatening than Muslim males.

Plus the conservatives would have burned down the billboards.

Think of it this way, if the networks would created a TV show about a gay 
couple, which do you think that Joe Sixpack would rather watch, a male 
couple or a female couple?
